channel.title: Windows shortcut to start a client
channel.description:
ok i didnt think there was a section for this so thats why i put it here. today i was like why hasnt anyone made a windows shortcut to start a client? so i did. the only reason i would think of, why they wouldnt is for debugging. b/c after the client closes so does the command prompt so if u had an error you wouldnt be able to read what it was. so if you want to know how to do it instead of using a batch file this is how you do it.
1. create a windows shortcut from either copying a shortcut from the desktop or creating a new one from the right click menu.
2.a if you copied the shortcut then rename it to "run" or w/e you want it to be called. open the properties of the shortcut from the right click menu. in the text box for the "target" change its contents to match what works with your computer and client:"C:\Path\to\your\jre" main class of the client the arguments for the main class an example would look like: ("C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre6\bin\java.exe" -Xmx1500m Gui 30 0 highmem members 32) After you have that information in the target box make sure the text box for "start in" is empty. then make sure the shortcut is in the same directory as the main class. [edit](Note: if you want to have the shortcut in another directory, then put the absolute path of the client class files directory in the text box "start in.")
2.b if you made a new shortcut, then follow the wizard to create the shortcut. then follow the steps of 2.a.
3rd. that should be it and you can use this method with other java application.
sorry for putting this in the wrong section. i didnt know it would go under general programming since it isnt really programming.

item.title: Windows shortcut to start a client
item.dc:creator: @abatssk8ter abatssk8ter
item.description:
@abatssk8ter wrote:

it’s alot simpler if you change the source file name to “bin” and put this as your run.bat
remember to add “cd bin”

@echo off title Running cd bin (JDK version and path shit) pause

then simply put the run.bat on your desktop and, bingo.

Read full topic
item.source: Windows shortcut to start a client

item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

thats what i thought. i didnt really expect it too, i just wanted to share what i found out so if someone thought that might use it they would know how. thx

item.title: Windows shortcut to start a client
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

He meant instead of using a shortcut, use pause so that the batch doesn’t close and you can see the error.

No offense, I do not believe this will benefit many. Although good try for a different alternate.

Read full topic
item.source: Windows shortcut to start a client

item.title: Windows shortcut to start a client
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“Muroth, post:7, topic:370576”]@echo off
java client
pause[/quote]
idk if you mean for that to be in a batch file? i know how to do batch files, i just posted this to make a shortcut(to all who doesnt understand. the file you click to open up most of your programs and folders. when you install most programs most of the time the installer gives you the option to create a shortcut on you desktop. again this post is about SHORTCUT FILES NOT BATCH FILES! sorry about all the confusion) instead of a batch “run” file. i dont think that will would in a windows shortcut.

Read full topic
item.source: Windows shortcut to start a client

item.title: Windows shortcut to start a client
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”][quote author=xryz link=topic=466679.msg3412740#msg3412740 date=1290828153]
(“C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre6\bin\java.exe” -Xmx1500m Gui 30 0 highmem members 32)[/quote]
You said, path to JRE, main class, then arguments, yet you use path, arguments, main class, and parameters. :P[/quote] well i thought arguments and parameters could be used almost interchangeably. and that was an example of one of the clients that i have. i didnt mention the jvm’s arguments b/c maybe someone may not use them. sorry if that confused anyone.

Read full topic

@Liquid_Magic wrote:

[quote=“xryz, post:3, topic:370576”]idk how u would use pause in a shortcut. well i was going search online on if it was possible through a shortcut to do a pause/2 commands. im not for sure but it looks like shortcut just runs a command prompt. if you wanted the shortcut in the start menu or on your desktop that would be easy. im not saying this is a better way i just wondered why i never since it done. i personally havent searched the web to see if someone else did it.[/quote]LOL
